text: Documentation should focus on {{c1::what}} the essential properties are, not {{c1::how}} these are implemented
back extra:
- “Whenever a ListRep object’s shared-field is false, it is used as representation of at most one List object”
Rather than:
- “When creating a new List object with an existing ListRep object, the shared-field is set to true”

text: Documentation contracts of {{c1::public methods}} should not refer to {{c2::private fields}}
back extra: (as clients may not have direct access to these fields)

text: {{c1::Coupling}} measures {{c2::interdependence}} between different {{c3::modules}}
Modules that {{c1::expose}} their {{c2::internal}} data representation become {{c3::tightly-coupled}} to their clients
{{c1::Information hiding}} is when we {{c2::hide implementation details behind the interface}}
With "No leaking" we mean that we {{c1::do not return references to sub-objects}}
Design patterns are {{c1::general, reusable solutions}} to commonly occuring design problems

2 Approaches for making code modular:
- {{c1::Restricting access to data fields}}
- {{c2::Making shared data immutable}}
The {{c1::flyweight}} pattern maximizes {{c2::sharing of immutable objects}}
In the {{c1::observer}} pattern components may {{c2::generate events}} or {{c3::register for events}} of other components using {{c4::a callback}}

Main strengths of Event-Based Style:
- {{c1::Reuse: plug in new components by registering them for events}}
- {{c2::Adaptation: add, remove, replace components with minimum effect on other components in the system}}

Weaknesses of event-based-style:
  • {{c1::Loss of control: In which order will the components be invoked?}}
  • {{c2::Ensuring correctness is difficult, because it depends on the context}}
{{c1::Inheritance}} couples the {{c2::sub}}-class to the {{c2::super}}-class
{{c1::Allocations}} couple the {{c2::clients}} to the {{c3::instantiated class}}
Modules can be made parametric by using {{c1::interfaces}} and {{c1::factories}} instead of {{c2::concrete classes}}
Modules can be made parametric by using {{c1::variable values}} instead of constant values
In Unit Testing we are testing {{c1::individual subsystems (collection of classes, or a single class)}}
{{c2::Exhaustive}} testing is when a unit is tested for {{c1::every possible input}}
{{c1::Random}} testing is when a unit is tested {{c2::with random inputs}}

What is the main disadvantage of random testing?
- {{c1::Treats all inputs as equally valuable}}
{{c1::Functional}} testing tests units by {{c2::using requirements knowledge to derive test cases}}

What is a limitation of functional testing?
- {{c1::Does not reveal errors in the specification (missing cases)}}
{{c1::Structural}} testing uses {{c2::design knowledge about the system structure, algorithms}} to {{c3::derive test cases that exercise a large portion of the code}}

What is a limitation for structural testing?
- {{c1::It requires design knowledge of the algorithm.}}
In {{c1::partition}} testing inputs are divided into {{c2::equivalence classes}}.
In {{c1::combinatorial}} testing we combine {{c2::equivalence classes}} and {{c3::boundary testing}}
CI stands for {{c1::continuous integration}}
CFG stands for {{c1::Control Flow Graph}}

An intraprocedural CFG of a procedure \(p\) is a graph (\(N\),\(E\)) where:
  • N is the set of {{c2::basic blocks in \(p\) plus designated entry and exit blocks}}
  • E contains
    • an edge from \(a\) to \(b\) with condition \(c\) iff {{c1::the execution of the basic block \(a\) is succeeded by the execution of \(b\) if the condition \(c\) holds}}
    • an edge (entry, \(a\), true) if {{c3::\(a\) is the first basic block of \(p\)}}
    • edges (\(b\), exit, true) {{c4::for each basic block \(b\) that ends with a return statement}}
Statement coverage is {{c1::how many of the statements were executed}}
Branch coverage tests {{c1::all the possible branches in the control flow}}
Branch coverage = {{c1::\(\frac{\text{Number of executed branches} }{\text{Total number of branches} }\)}}
Statement coverage = {{c1::\(\frac{\text{Number of executed statements} }{\text{Total number of statements} }\)}}
Branch coverage leads to {{c1::more}} thorough testing than statement coverage
Path coverage tests {{c1::all possible paths through the CFG}}
Path coverage = {{c1::\(\frac{\text{Number of executed paths} }{\text{Total number of paths} }\)}}
Path coverage leads to {{c1::more}} thorough testing than both statement and branch coverage
Loop coverage = {{c1::\(\frac{\binom{\text{Number of executed loops} }{\text{with 0,1 and more than 1 iterations} } }{\text{Total number of loops * 3} }\)}}
In loop coverage, for each loop, test {{c1::zero, one and more than one consecutive iterations}}
Statement coverage leads to {{c1::less}} thorough testing than branch coverage
Statement and branch coverage lead to {{c1::less}} thorough testing than path coverage
A {{c2::join}} between A and B is denoted as {{c1::\(A \sqcup B\)}}
A {{c1::complete lattice}} (L, \(\sqsubseteq\), \(\sqcup\)) is a {{c2::poset}} where {{c3::\(\sqcup Y\) and \(\sqcap Y\)}} exist for any \(Y\subseteq L\)
back extra:
(For example, for a set \(L\), \((\mathcal{P}(L),\subseteq, \cup, \cap)\) is a complete
lattice.)

text: A {{c1::function f}}: \(A \to B\) between two posets (A, \(\sqsubseteq\)) and (B, \(\leq\)) is {{c2::increasing (monotone)}}: \(\forall a,b\in A:\) {{c3::\(a\sqsubseteq b\Rightarrow f(a)\leq f(b)\)}}

For a poset (L, \(\sqsubseteq\)), function f: \(L\to L\), and element \(x\in L\):
- x is a {{c1::fixed point}} iff f(x) = x
{{c2::Fix(f)}} denotes the set of all {{c1::fixed points}}
{{c2::Red(f)}} denotes the set of all {{c1::post-fixedpoints}}
For a poset (L, \(\sqsubseteq\)), function \(f:L\to L\), we say that {{c2::\(lfp^\sqsubseteq f\)}} \(\in L\) is a {{c1::least fixed point}} of \(f\)

For a poset (L, \(\sqsubseteq\)), function \(f:L\to L\), we say that {{c2::\(\text{lfp}^\sqsubseteq f\)}} \(\in L\) is a {{c1::least fixed point}} of \(f\) if:
  • {{c3::\(\text{lfp}^\sqsubseteq f\) is a fixed point.}}
  • {{c4::It is the least fixed point: \(\forall a\in L: a = f(a) \Rightarrow lfp^\sqsubseteq f\sqsubseteq a\)}}

{{c1::Tarski's fixed point}} theorem: 
If \((L,\sqsubseteq,\sqcup,\sqcap,\bot,\top)\) is a {{c4::complete lattice}} and \(f:L\to L\) is a {{c5::monotone function}}, then:
{{c2::\(\text{lfp}^\sqsubseteq f\) exists}}, and
\({{c2::\text{lfp}^\sqsubseteq f}} = {{c3::\sqcap \text{ Red}(f)\in \text{Fix}(f)}}\)
{{c1::Tarski}}'s theorem tells us that a fixed point exists, but {{c2::does not actually suggest an algorithm for computing it}}.

Given a poset of {{c1::finite height}}, a {{c1::least element}} \(\bot\), a {{c1::monotone}} \(f\).

Then the iterates \(f^0(\bot), f^1(\bot), f^2(\bot), \ldots\) eventually stabilize for some \(n\in N\), that is:
\(f^{{{c2::n}} }(\bot)=f^{{{c2::n+1}}}(\bot)\) and:
\({{c3::lfp^\sqsubseteq f}}={{c4::f^n(\bot)}}\)
{{c2::\([\![P]\!]\)}} is the {{c1::set of reachable states of a program \(P\)}}

Given functions:
\(F:C\to C\)
\(F^\#:A\to A\)
what does it mean for \(F^\#\) to approximate \(F\)?
\(\forall x\in C: {{c1::F(x)\sqsubseteq_C F^\#(x)}}\)

How to approximate a function given:
\(F:X\to X\)
\(F^\#:Y\to Y\)
{{c2::\(Y\)}} is the {{c1::abstract}} and {{c2::\(X\)}} is the {{c1::concrete}}

How to approximate a function given:
\(F:C\to C\)
\(F^\#:A\to A\)
We need to connect the {{c1::concrete \(C\)}} and the {{c1::abstract \(A\)}}

How to approximate a function given:
\(F:C\to C\)
\(F^\#:A\to A\)

{{c2::\(\alpha:C\to A\)}} is called the {{c1::abstraction}} function
{{c2:: \(\gamma:A\to C\)}} is called the {{c1::concretization}} function
The {{c2::least precise}} approximation for \(F\) is simply {{c1::\(F^\#(z)=\top\)}}
back extra: (However, it is not practically useful as it is too imprecise. It is always sound.)

text: The {{c2::most precise}} approximation for \(F\) is {{c1::\(F^\#(z)=\alpha(F(\gamma(z)))\)}}
{{c2::\([\![action]\!]\)}} is often referred to as the {{c1::abstract transformer}}
\([\![action]\!]\)captures the {{c1::abstract semantics of the language}}

Mathematical Concept:
{{c2::Bottom \((\bot)\)}}

Use in Static Analysis:
{{c1::Used for initialization of all but initial elements}}

Mathematical Concept:
{{c2::Joins \((\sqcup)\)}}

Use in Static Analysis:
{{c1::Combines facts arriving at a program point}}

Mathematical Concept:
{{c2::Complete Lattice}}

Use in Static Analysis:
{{c1::Defines Abstract Domain and ensure joins exist}}

Mathematical Concept:
{{c2::Widening \((\triangledown)\)}}

Use in Static Analysis:
{{c1::Used to guarantee analysis termination}}

Mathematical Concept:
{{c2::Tarski's Theorem}}

Use in Static Analysis:
{{c1::Ensures fixed points exist}}

Example of lifting:
We have x, y, and we lift to \(\text{Var}\to L^i\):

Let map1 be: \(\{x\to[1,5], y\to[7,10]\}\)
Let map2 be: \(\{x\to[2,6], y\to[6,9]\}\)

Then
  • map3 = (map1 \(\sqcap\) map2) = {{c2::\(\{x\to[2,5], y\to[7,9]\}\)}}
  • map4 = (map1 \(\sqcup\) map2) = {{c2::\(\{x\to[1,6], y\to[6,10]\}\)}}
  • (map3 \(\sqsubseteq\) map4) is {{c1::true}}
If we add \(\bot_i\) to any other element, we get {{c1::\(\bot_i\)}}

If both operands are not \(\bot_i\), we get:
\([x,y] + [p,q] = {{c1::[x+p, y+q]}}\)
The operator {{c1::\(\triangledown: L\times L\to L\)}} is called a {{c2::widening}} operator

The operator \(\triangledown: L\times L\to L\) is called a widening operator if:
  • {{c2::\(\forall a,b\in L: a\sqcup b\sqsubseteq a\triangledown b\) (widening approximates the join)}}
  • if \(x^0\sqsubseteq x^1\sqsubseteq x^2 \sqsubseteq\ldots\sqsubseteq x^n\) is {{c3::an increasing sequence}},
    then \(y^0\sqsubseteq y^1\sqsubseteq y^2 \sqsubseteq\ldots\sqsubseteq y^n\) {{c4::stabilizes after a finite number of steps}}
    where \(y^0=x^0\) and \(\forall i\geq 0: y^{i+1}={{c1::y^i\triangledown x^{i+1} }}\)
The fixed point is the {{c1::over-approximation}} of the program
We select/define an abstract domain based on the {{c1::type of properties we want to prove}}

Interval Domain:
\([a,b]\sqsubseteq_i [c,d]\) if {{c1::\(a\geq c, b \leq d\)}}

Interval Domain:
\([a,b]\sqcup_i [c,d] = {{c1::[\min(\{a,c\}), \;\max(\{b,d\})] }}\)
{{c2::\(\text{wdi}(a,b)\)}} is the {{c1::well-defined interval}}
\(L^i\) domain defines {{c1::intervals}}
\(\text{Var}\) defines the {{c1::variables}} in a program
\(\text{Lab} \to (\text{Var} \to \text{L}^i)\) means that {{c1::at each label}} and {{c1::for each variable}}, we will {{c2::keep the interval for that variable}}

Generic Template:
\(F^\#: {{c1::(Lab \to A)}} \to {{c1::(Lab \to A)}}\)

What is \((\ell',\text{action},\ell)\)?

({{c1::program counter}}, {{c1::action that will be executed}}, {{c1::next program counter}})
\((\ell',\text{action},\ell)\) is an {{c1::edge}} in the control-flow graph

If there exists a transition \(t=\langle\ell',\sigma'\rangle\to\langle\ell,\sigma\rangle\) in a program trace in \(P\), then {{c1::\((\ell',\text{action},\ell)\)}} must exist.
This says that we are {{c2::sound}}: {{c2::we never miss a flow}}
Iterate abstract transformers over the {{c2::abstract domain}} until {{c1::we reach a fixed point}}
The solution to {{c1::a function that keeps iterating}} is to use the {{c2::widening}} operator
Widening approximates the {{c1::join}}

\([a,b]\triangledown[c,d] = [e,f]\) where:
  • if {{c1::\(a>c\)}}, then {{c1::\(e=-\infty\)}}, else {{c1::\(e=a\)}}
  • if {{c1::\(b<d\)}}, then {{c1::\(f=\infty\)}}, else {{c1::\(f=b\)}}
For \([a,b]\triangledown[c,d] = [e,f]\), if one of the operands is \(\bot\) the result is {{c1::the other operand}}.
When using the widening operator we are able to reach a {{c1::fixed point}} in a program where there is a variable that keeps increasing
back extra: Notice the \([7,\infty]\) that happen because \(y\) is at least 7 at those points and always increases with each iteration

text:
Looking at the concrete store:
  • \(\text{Objs}\) is the {{c1::set of all possible objects}}
  • \(\text{PtrVal} = {{c2::\text{Objs}\cup\{\text{null}\} }}\)
Two pointers are {{c1::aliases}} if {{c2::they point to the same object}}
{{c2::Points-to pair (p,A)}} means {{c1::p holds the address of object A}}

Using allocation sites (labels), abstract objects are defined as:
\(\text{AbsObj}={{c1::\{\ell\;|\;\text{statement is }p:=\text{alloc}^\ell\} }}\)

Two kinds of pointer analysis:
  • {{c1::Flow sensitive}}
  • {{c1::Flow insensitive}}
Flow {{c2::sensitive}} pointer analysis {{c1::respects the program control flow}}
Flow {{c2::insensitive}} pointer analysis {{c1::assumes all execution orders are possible (abstracts away order between statements)}}
Flow {{c2::insensitive}} pointer analysis is good for {{c1::concurrency (if not too imprecise)}}

Two pointers a and b may alias if:
{{c1::points-to (a) \(\cap\) points-to (b) \(\neq \emptyset\)}}
A function points-to (p) returns the {{c1::set of all abstract objects that a pointer p can point to}}

Sources of unboundedness:
  • Unbounded {{c1::heap}}
  • Unbounded {{c1::range of array indices}}
  • Unbounded {{c1::number of threads}}
ALoc stands for {{c1::abstract location}}
Widening (\(\triangledown\)) operator jumps {{c1::upwards (above least fixedpoint)}}
Widening (\(\triangledown\)) ensures {{c1::termination}}
Widening (\(\triangledown\)) operator {{c1::costs/reduces}} precision
Narrowing (\(\triangle\)) operator jumps {{c1::downwards (but stays above least fixedpoint)}}
Narrowing (\(\triangle\)) operator {{c1::improves}} precision
{{c2::Forwards}} analysis overapproximates {{c1::output}} state from {{c1::input}} state
{{c2::Backwards}} analysis overapproximates {{c1::input}} state from {{c1::output}} state
{{c1::Forwards}} analysis computes {{c2::postcondition from given precondition}}
{{c1::Backwards}} analysis computes {{c2::precondition avoiding given postcondition}}

How do we combine facts in may-analysis vs must-analysis?
  • May: {{c1::overapprox. via join}}
  • Must: {{c1::underapprox. via meet}}

What are the main limitations of SMT solvers?
  • {{c1::Many theories aren't decidable (e.g. non-linear integers)}}
  • {{c1::Constraint solving may take too long}}
{{c2::Concolic execution}} combines {{c1::concrete}} and {{c1::symbolic}} execution
The high-level idea in the concolic execution is that the {{c1::concrete execution drives the symbolic one}}
Concolic execution uses a solver to {{c1::query legal values to go down the other branch}}
back extra: And then all the paths have been explored

text: Symbolically executing native code is difficult/impossible because {{c1::sources may not be available}} or {{c1::written in an unsupported language}}
Static analysis is the {{c1::over}}-approximation
Dynamic analysis is the {{c1::under}}-approximation
Symbolic execution is the {{c1::over- & under}}-approximation
Core idea of symbolic execution is to {{c1::compute the symbolic constraints per path, and then solve these constraints to have inputs that explore all paths}}
Path conditions \(\pi\) are the {{c1::conditions under which a path is taken}}
We have a symbolic state per {{c1::program point}}
Facts add {{c1::constraints that always hold}}
The Alloy Analyzer is decidable, because {{c1::it searches for structures up to a given size making the problem become finite}}
In linear temporal logic the \(\phi\) symbol denotes {{c1::what holds now}}
In linear temporal logic \(X\phi\) or \(\circ\phi\) denotes {{c1::that \(\phi\) holds in the next step}}
In linear temporal logic \(\phi U \psi\) denotes {{c1::that \(\phi\) holds until \(\psi\) holds}}
In linear temporal logic \(F\phi\) or \(\diamond\phi\) denotes {{c1::that \(\phi\) holds eventually}}
In linear temporal logic \(G\phi\) or \(\square\phi\) denotes {{c1::that \(\phi\) always holds}}
